channel.title: Hard Drive password?
channel.description: Well at my 6th form in the IT tech office today we had a laptop brought to us and some idiot has set a password on the hard drive, so basically it cant be booted into at all, the BIOS asks for the password and 3 incorrect attempts moves on to the next booting device on the list. Anyone got a way to fix this? otherwise we've got to spend £89 on a new laptop hard drive for the school and that budget is needed elsewhere really

item.title: Hard Drive password?
item.dc:creator: @sanga282 sanga282
item.description:
@sanga282 wrote:

i linked my boss to this page today he was reading all the comments just see what he has to say about it when i go in before my exams tomorrow

Read full topic

item.title: Hard Drive password?
item.dc:creator: @Fat_Cookies Fat Cookies
item.description:
@Fat_Cookies wrote:

On another topic

What’s wrong with my suggestion then?

Expensive.
You cant use a electromagnet but whats wrong with UV light on the correct chip?

Read full topic

item.title: Hard Drive password?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“runescape3dude, post:18, topic:278381”][quote author=sanga282 link=topic=367394.msg2787254#msg2787254 date=1242551412]

Bullshit, an 80gb laptop hard disk was only $15US last year. I doubt it has gone up.

thats in america you idiot, one we’re in the UK and secondly we’re a school so everything has to go through proper channels along with tests performed on it to make sure its working correctly and so on its a lengthy and expensive process.
[/quote]
Im in kiwiland. Would cost less if was bought in NZ… + Schools usually just salvage stuff. Also, try to use an electro magnet on it.(In all the movies… See what it really does?)[/quote]

The password is probably stored on a flash chip instead of the actual disk platter, so a magnet wouldn’t do anything.

Read full topic

item.description:

Im in kiwiland. Would cost less if was bought in NZ… + Schools usually just salvage stuff. Also, try to use an electro magnet on it.(In all the movies… See what it really does?)

item.title: Hard Drive password?
item.dc:creator: @Fat_Cookies Fat Cookies
item.description:
@Fat_Cookies wrote:

[quote=“sanga282, post:15, topic:278381”][quote author=My Boss]
Sadly you can only flash the hard drive when it’s unlocked in the first place. As you need to get too a boot stage. Only BIOS (I think) can be flashed before devices are initialised.
[/quote]
I emailed my boss the idea this is what he replied[/quote]

Well if you can an OS booted from a CD use http://www.ultimatebootcd.com/ and use the ATA Password Tool which claims to remove a HD password from any *ATA hardisk (However the websites only makes a refernece to an IDE disk).

If your just plain stupid and daring I read somewhere that there is a specific EEPROM chip that only contains the password and if you manage to open it, (Dont ask how) exposing it to UV light for 10 minutes will flash it.

While discovering ultimate boot CD I also discovered Rockbox which is a free open source mp3/mp4 player firmware for devices like those Archos’ and even Ipods. (It relates to the password thing because when replacing the firmware on some hard drives the password can get locked.)


Thats just an example on an Ipod Video.

Read full topic

item.title: Hard Drive password?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“sanga282, post:15, topic:278381”][quote author=My Boss]
Sadly you can only flash the hard drive when it’s unlocked in the first place. As you need to get too a boot stage. Only BIOS (I think) can be flashed before devices are initialised.
[/quote]
I emailed my boss the idea this is what he replied[/quote]

Call the hardware manufacturer, there has to be a way around this. Maybe a default password or a password reset jumper.

Read full topic

item.title: Hard Drive password?
item.dc:creator: @sanga282 sanga282
item.description:
@sanga282 wrote:

My Boss:

Sadly you can only flash the hard drive when it’s unlocked in the first place. As you need to get too a boot stage. Only BIOS (I think) can be flashed before devices are initialised.

I emailed my boss the idea this is what he replied

Read full topic

item.title: Hard Drive password?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“Fat Cookies, post:11, topic:278381”]I know understand that you cannot format it but you can flash the firmware?

I heard that IBM provide a bootable CD that can flash various hard disks. You should google it and give it a go.[/quote]

Flashing a new firmware on the hard drive should take care of it.

Read full topic

item.title: Hard Drive password?
item.dc:creator: @eczema3 eczema3
item.description:
@eczema3 wrote:

Set the secondary boot device to CD drive, load a linux OS up, take any data that is needed and put it somewhere else then blank the hard drive.

Read full topic

item.title: Hard Drive password?
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

I know I can hotswap it. But, My E partition on the XB HDD was corrupt, and I had to unlock it, and it wouldn’t let me unlock it because the E was missing, so I had to use the serial port trick, use a linux disc to reformat it, and then it worked. But the device might reduce all that time.

Read full topic

item.title: Hard Drive password?
item.dc:creator: @sanga282 sanga282
item.description:
@sanga282 wrote:

[quote=“Fat Cookies, post:6, topic:278381”][quote author=zyle1992 link=topic=367394.msg2783714#msg2783714 date=1242341049]
I know what he’s talking about… I modded my Xbox a while ago, and had to find the HDD pass out the hard way. I had to get to one of the chips on the mobo, and hook up some wires to the legs, and send the data through the serial port, and find it out that way… Not sure if the process is the same for a laptop. This might be beneficial for your company though. It brute forces the pass of a hard drive.

http://www.yec-usa.com/products/shinobi.html
[/quote]
Zyle, you know you can just hotswap an Xbox with your pc and unlock it that way.

I know I relate everything to live CDs, but try a Linux Live CD and see if you can mount the hard disk and check if you can change anything or format.[/quote]
formatting it wont work the password is in the hard drives firmware that wont reset with a format

Read full topic

item.title: Hard Drive password?
item.dc:creator: @Fat_Cookies Fat Cookies
item.description:
@Fat_Cookies wrote:

[quote=“zyle1992, post:3, topic:278381”]I know what he’s talking about… I modded my Xbox a while ago, and had to find the HDD pass out the hard way. I had to get to one of the chips on the mobo, and hook up some wires to the legs, and send the data through the serial port, and find it out that way… Not sure if the process is the same for a laptop. This might be beneficial for your company though. It brute forces the pass of a hard drive.

http://www.yec-usa.com/products/shinobi.html[/quote]
Zyle, you know you can just hotswap an Xbox with your pc and unlock it that way.

I know I relate everything to live CDs, but try a Linux Live CD and see if you can mount the hard disk and check if you can change anything or format.

Read full topic
